title: How to Change an Outlook Email Account Password on PC, Mac, & Web

steps.title: Click the profile icon in Outlook and select My Microsoft account.
steps.content: Click the profile icon in Outlook and select My Microsoft account . You'll see the profile icon at the top-right corner of Outlook.com when you're logged in. This takes you to your Microsoft account management page. Because your Microsoft password and your Outlook.com passwords are the same, you'll need to change your Microsoft password in your account info. This will change the password for all of your Microsoft services. You can also go to https://account.microsoft.com directly.

steps.title: Click Change password.
steps.content: Click Change password . It's at the top-right corner of your Microsoft account page.

steps.title: Log in with your current password.
steps.content: Log in with your current password. If you don’t remember your password, click the Forgot password? link to reset it. [1] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source Depending on your security settings, you may have to perform a second step, such as enter a code that's sent to you via text or the Microsoft Authenticator app.

steps.title: Enter a new password and click Save.
steps.content: Enter a new password and click Save . To change your Outlook email password, you'll need to enter your current password, type your new password, and then reenter it to ensure it matches. Once you're finished, click Save to change your password.

steps.title: Change your password through your email service provider.
steps.content: Change your password through your email service provider. If you use Outlook for Windows to send and receive email through your work, school, or a third-party email service (including Gmail , Yahoo , or an ISP like Xfinity), you'll first need to change your password through that service. Once your password is changed, you can update Outlook with the new password. If you use Outlook.com, Live.com, Hotmail.com, or a domain name connected to your Microsoft account, you will need to change your Microsoft password at https://account.microsoft.com . [2] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source Contact your ISP or admin if you're not sure how to change your email server password.

steps.title: Open Outlook and check your email.
steps.content: Open Outlook and check your email. If you're using Outlook Classic, click the Send / Receive tab, then click Send/Receive All Folders . If your old password does not match your new one, you will see a pop-up asking you to enter a new password. In New Outlook, Outlook will try to check your email automatically and display a password error when it cannot connect.

steps.title: Enter your new password to update it.
steps.content: Enter your new password to update it. As long as the password you enter matches the new password you created through your email service, Outlook will save the password and send/receive any emails. steps.title: Change your password through your email service provider.
steps.content: Change your password through your email service provider. If you use Outlook for Mac to send and receive email through your work, school, or a third-party email service (including Gmail , iCloud , or an ISP like Xfinity), you'll first need to change your password through that service. Once your password is changed, you can update Outlook with the new password.

steps.title: Open Outlook and click the Tools menu.
steps.content: Open Outlook and click the Tools menu. You'll see it at the top of the screen when Outlook is open. [4] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Click the account you want to update.
steps.content: Click the account you want to update. You'll see your added accounts in the left panel.

steps.title: Click the circle with a lightning bolt inside.
steps.content: Click the circle with a lightning bolt inside. You'll see this icon next to your account name if the password saved in Outlook doesn't match the new password on the server.

steps.title: Follow the on-screen prompts to log in with your new password.
steps.content: Follow the on-screen prompts to log in with your new password. If you are using Outlook to check your Microsoft account email, you'll be prompted to log in with your Microsoft account. If your email is through another service, you'll be prompted to log in to that service, or just enter your new password. Once the password is accepted, Outlook will save your new email password.

steps.title: Click the File menu and select Info.
steps.content: Click the File menu and select Info . This will display the "Account Information" screen. If you haven't already changed your password through your email provider, such as through your work, school, or ISP account, you will need to do that first. Once your email account's password has changed, you can use this method to update that password in Outlook.

steps.title: Click the Account Settings tile.
steps.content: Click the Account Settings tile. This opens another menu.

steps.title: Click Account Settings….
steps.content: Click Account Settings… . You'll see a pop-up containing a list of email accounts you've added to Outlook.

steps.title: Select your email account and click Change.
steps.content: Select your email account and click Change . The Change button is just above the list of accounts.

steps.title: Update your password.
steps.content: Update your password. Replace the current password with your new password, and check the "Remember password" box. If you use a password to authenticate for SMTP, you can change that password by clicking More Settings , selecting the Outgoing server tab, and replacing the password there.

steps.title: Click Next and follow the on-screen instructions to confirm.
steps.content: Click Next and follow the on-screen instructions to confirm. Once your password is accepted, it will be saved in Outlook.

steps.title: Click the Tools menu at the top of Outlook.
steps.content: Click the Tools menu at the top of Outlook. If you've changed your email account password through your email service provider, use this method to update older versions of Outlook to use the right password. If you haven't already changed your password through your email provider, such as through your work, school, or ISP account, you will need to do that first. Once your email account's password has changed, you can use this method to update that password in Outlook.

steps.title: Click Account Settings.
steps.content: Click Account Settings . If you're using Outlook 2003, select View or change existing email accounts .

steps.title: Select your email account and click Change.
steps.content: Select your email account and click Change . The Change button is just above the list of accounts.

steps.title: Update your password.
steps.content: Update your password. Replace the current password with your new password, and check the "Remember password" box. If you use a password to authenticate for SMTP, you can change that password by clicking More Settings , selecting the Outgoing server tab, and replacing the password there.

steps.title: Click Next and follow the on-screen instructions to confirm.
steps.content: Click Next and follow the on-screen instructions to confirm. Once your password is accepted, it will be saved in Outlook.

steps.title: Open Outlook Classic.
steps.content: Open Outlook Classic. New Outlook does not currently support PST files, so you can't use it to change the password on a PST data file. If you need to do so, you'll have to switch back to Outlook Classic. If you're using Outlook Classic already, you'll see a slider at the top-right that says "Try the new Outlook." You don't have to do anything if you see this. If you're using New Outlook, the slider will say "New Outlook." Click the toggle switch to switch back to Outlook Classic.

steps.title: Click the File menu and select Account Settings.
steps.content: Click the File menu and select Account Settings . You'll see the "File" tab at the top, and "Account Settings when you open the menu. A menu will expand.

steps.title: Click Account Settings… on the menu.
steps.content: Click Account Settings… on the menu. This opens the Account Settings panel.

steps.title: Click the Data Files tab.
steps.content: Click the Data Files tab. A list of added PST and OST files will appear. You cannot change the password of an OST file. [5] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Select the data file and click Settings….
steps.content: Select the data file and click Settings… .

steps.title: Click Change Password….
steps.content: Click Change Password… . This option is only available if you're not using a Microsoft Exchange account and not trying to change an OST password.

steps.title: Enter the old password.
steps.content: Enter the old password. You can only change the password if you know the old password. If you lost the old PST file password, there is no way to reset it.

steps.title: Enter a new password and click OK.
steps.content: Enter a new password and click OK . You will need to enter the new password twice to confirm. It.

steps.title: Sign in to the Outlook Web App for your organization.
steps.content: Sign in to the Outlook Web App for your organization. If your work or school account requires you to use the Outlook Web App to send and receive email, you can change your password easily in any browser. This method only applies if your organization uses Exchange Server 2013 or 2010.

steps.title: Click the gear icon and select Change password.
steps.content: Click the gear icon and select Change password . You'll see the gear icon at the top-right corner.

steps.title: Follow the on-screen instructions to change your password.
steps.content: Follow the on-screen instructions to change your password. Use a minimum of 8 characters and a mix of capital and lowercase letters, numbers, and punctuation marks. [6] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source
